title: China Ministry of Commerce and National School of Administration hold training seminar for Cuban cadres
description: On 21 November, 2016, the opening ceremony of the Overseas Seminar on Capacity Building for Cuban Cadres was held.  This training class is a direct result of the foreign aid training program established between both countries.  The class is sponsored by China's Ministry of Commerce and specifically undertaken and implemented by the China National School of Administration.  It is a new attempt by China to actively participate in the renewal of the Cuban economic model. The seminar will be conducted by senior experts from the National School of Administration of China on China’s political system, social governance, legal system, economic and social development.
staff_comments: The Chinese training program name is 古巴干部能力建设 (See: 陈曦大使出席“古巴干部能力建设”援外海外研修班开班仪式).The seminar captured in this project may be related to the training programs for state and government cadres established in project #71176.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China Ministry of Commerce and National School of Administration hold training seminar for Cuban cadres

# Description
On 21 November, 2016, the opening ceremony of the Overseas Seminar on Capacity Building for Cuban Cadres was held.  This training class is a direct result of the foreign aid training program established between both countries.  The class is sponsored by China's Ministry of Commerce and specifically undertaken and implemented by the China National School of Administration.  It is a new attempt by China to actively participate in the renewal of the Cuban economic model. The seminar will be conducted by senior experts from the National School of Administration of China on China’s political system, social governance, legal system, economic and social development.
justification: Project focuses on capacity building and knowledge transfer without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Training seminar for Cuban cadres, focus on political system, social governance, and economic development

title: China Eximbank provides a loan to Cuba for the Tractor Purchase Project
description: In 2016, China Eximbank provided a loan to the Cuban Ministry of Finance and Prices for the purchase of YTO medium and high power tractors, known as the Tractor Purchase Project. The loan terms are unknown. The purpose of the tractors is to increase local rice production.  The 2017 annual report from YTO, indicates that there may be more than one Cuban state enterprise involved in buying tractors from the Chinese company--this include: Cuba TRANSIMPORT, Cuba TECNOIMPORT, AZUIMPORT, QUIMIMPEX, CUBA ENERGOIMPORT, IMECO, CUBA CITRICOS CARIB, UBA EMPRESA IMPORTADORA, and EMIAT. Cuba TECNOIMPORT, was the client with the highest ending balance that year. According to the consolidated balance sheet from December, 31, 2019, Cuba TECNOIMPORT had a balance of 24,922,379.40 RMB indicating that the project may still be in the implementation stage.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 拖拖拉机采购项目.This project is different from the export credits agreement captured in Project #70189. According to a Chinese government source, two loans and one PBC agreement were signed that day for the purchase of tractors (See: http://cu.mofcom.gov.cn/article/todayheader/201602/20160201263974.shtml). A Cuban source says the loan captured in this project is the 4th tranche-- a 5th tranche is in the works-- so we know that there are multiple facilities being used for the same goal (See https://cubainformacion.tv/cuba/20160223/67367/67367-banco-chino-concede-nuevo-credito-a-cuba-para-compra-de-tractores-y-trenes).
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank provides a loan to Cuba for the Tractor Purchase Project

# Description
In 2016, China Eximbank provided a loan to the Cuban Ministry of Finance and Prices for the purchase of YTO medium and high power tractors, known as the Tractor Purchase Project. The loan terms are unknown. The purpose of the tractors is to increase local rice production.  The 2017 annual report from YTO, indicates that there may be more than one Cuban state enterprise involved in buying tractors from the Chinese company--this include: Cuba TRANSIMPORT, Cuba TECNOIMPORT, AZUIMPORT, QUIMIMPEX, CUBA ENERGOIMPORT, IMECO, CUBA CITRICOS CARIB, UBA EMPRESA IMPORTADORA, and EMIAT. Cuba TECNOIMPORT, was the client with the highest ending balance that year. According to the consolidated balance sheet from December, 31, 2019, Cuba TECNOIMPORT had a balance of 24,922,379.40 RMB indicating that the project may still be in the implementation stage.
justification: Project focuses on agricultural equipment purchase without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Purchase of YTO tractors for increasing local rice production, no mention of energy or environmental aspects

title: Chinese Government reschedules $3.17 billion of Cuba’s outstanding debt in 2016 (Linked to Project ID#39195 and #54691)
description: In 2016, the Chinese Government reportedly forgave 42.7% ($2.83 billion) of the Cuban's Government's outstanding debt obligations (worth $6 billion). The Chinese Government reportedly rescheduled the remaining 52.8% of the the Cuban Government's outstanding debt obligations (worth $3.17 billion). The exact terms of the restructuring are unknown. However, one source suggests that 5 years of additional grace was provided as well as an interest rate reduction.
staff_comments: 1. The Cuban Government's 2016 debt cancellation agreement with the Chinese Government came shortly after the Cuban Government rescheduled its debts with Paris Club creditors in December 2015. The 2015 Paris Club agreement with the Cuban Government, seen by Reuters, forgave $8.5 billion of the Cuban Government's outstanding debt obligations (worth $11.1 billion). These obligations resulted from debts that the Cuban Government defaulted on in 1986, plus charges. Under the terms of the 2015 agreement, repayment of the outstanding debt in annual installments was back loaded through 2033. In exchange, the Cuban Government agreed to pay the remaining principal ($2.6 billion) that it owed Paris Club creditors since its 1986 default over an 18-year period. The Paris Club is an informal group of creditor governments from Australia, Austria, Belgium, Britain, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, Norway, Russia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United States. 2. As of October 2020, Recardo Cabrisas (Ricardo Cabrisas) was Cuba's chief debt negotiator. 3. The Chinese Government's 2011 debt restructuring of Cuban debt is captured via Project ID#39195.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
Chinese Government reschedules $3.17 billion of Cuba’s outstanding debt in 2016 (Linked to Project ID#39195 and #54691)

# Description
In 2016, the Chinese Government reportedly forgave 42.7% ($2.83 billion) of the Cuban's Government's outstanding debt obligations (worth $6 billion). The Chinese Government reportedly rescheduled the remaining 52.8% of the the Cuban Government's outstanding debt obligations (worth $3.17 billion). The exact terms of the restructuring are unknown. However, one source suggests that 5 years of additional grace was provided as well as an interest rate reduction.
justification: Debt rescheduling and forgiveness is a financial service with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Debt restructuring and forgiveness, no specific project details provided

title: China offers 20 million yuan of aid to North Korea in response to flooding
description: On November 2, 2016, China provided 20 million yuan (approx 2.9 million USD) in humanitarian aid to flood-hit North Korea upon request by the DPRK government. According to the Ministry of Commerce, the 20 million yuan aid will be used for emergency response and post-disaster recovery and reconstruction.  Around 70,000 North Koreans were left homeless after their houses were destroyed by floodwaters in North Hamgyong, a province in northeastern North Korea. Furthermore, according to the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, around 18,600 households were totally destroyed by the flood and over 11,400 homes sustained damage.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China offers 20 million yuan of aid to North Korea in response to flooding

# Description
On November 2, 2016, China provided 20 million yuan (approx 2.9 million USD) in humanitarian aid to flood-hit North Korea upon request by the DPRK government. According to the Ministry of Commerce, the 20 million yuan aid will be used for emergency response and post-disaster recovery and reconstruction.  Around 70,000 North Koreans were left homeless after their houses were destroyed by floodwaters in North Hamgyong, a province in northeastern North Korea. Furthermore, according to the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, around 18,600 households were totally destroyed by the flood and over 11,400 homes sustained damage.
justification: Humanitarian aid for emergency response and disaster recovery with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: 20 million yuan aid for flood response and reconstruction, focus on emergency relief and housing recovery

title: Chinese Government provides 500,000 tons of food aid in 2016
description: On June 2016, the Chinese Government agreed to provide 500,000 tons of food aid to North Korea when the North Korean Workers' Party Vice Chairman Ri Su Yong and his delegation visited China to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping. Delivering a letter written by Kim Jong Un, Vice Chairman Ri Su Yong requested one million tons of food, but President Xi reportedly agreed to provide only 500,000 tons. It remains uncertain if the Chinese Government ultimately corn, rice, or both. However, in early August 2016, 20-ton trucks transporting corn to North Korea were spotted on the border between North Korea and China. The estimated monetary value of this donation is $79,610,000
staff_comments: 1. To estimate the monetary value of the donation ($79,610,000), AidData takes the international price of a ton of maize in 2016 ($159.22) and multiplies it by 500,000 tons.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
Chinese Government provides 500,000 tons of food aid in 2016

# Description
On June 2016, the Chinese Government agreed to provide 500,000 tons of food aid to North Korea when the North Korean Workers' Party Vice Chairman Ri Su Yong and his delegation visited China to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping. Delivering a letter written by Kim Jong Un, Vice Chairman Ri Su Yong requested one million tons of food, but President Xi reportedly agreed to provide only 500,000 tons. It remains uncertain if the Chinese Government ultimately corn, rice, or both. However, in early August 2016, 20-ton trucks transporting corn to North Korea were spotted on the border between North Korea and China. The estimated monetary value of this donation is $79,610,000
justification: Project is focused on food aid and security assistance, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: 500,000 tons of food aid, developmental food security assistance

title: Chinese Government donates 500,000 tons of crude oil in 2016
description: In 2016, the Chinese Government donated approximately 500,000 tons of crude oil to the North Korean Government. 500,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 3,665,000 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($158,657,850), AidData has taken the average price ($43.29) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) crude oil in 2016 and multiplied it by 3,665,000 barrels of oil. This crude oil donation project was supported via recurring grants from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) between 2000 and 2017.  Since 1991, China has been North Korea's largest crude oil provider, making up 80% of its supply. Crude oil is provided to North Korea through a pipeline (known as the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline or Friendship Oil Pipeline) from the Daqing Oil Field, 800 kilometers north of the China-North Korea border. The pipeline, which was completed in December 1975, runs for more than 30 km from storage facilities in the Chinese border city of Dandong to an oil depot in Sinuiju in North Korea. It supplies approximately 520,000 tons (3.64 million barrels) of heavy crude oil each year, according to its operator, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC). Once across the border, the crude oil is processed at North Korea's sole working refinery, the Ponghwa Chemical Factory, a facility built with Chinese assistance during the 1970s. The refinery turns the oil into refined products for North Korea's government, military, transport, agricultural and fishing sectors.
staff_comments: 1. In 2012, a North Korean source disclosed that every year ‘the Ministry of Commerce of China and the North Korean government will discuss the catalogue of aid products, quantity, period, etc., but it is basically 100,000 tons of grain, 500,000 tons of oil, and materials needed by North Korea worth 20 million US dollars.’  2. This annual oil donation arrangement between the Chinese Government and the North Korean Government dates back to the 1970s. On October 17, 1970, the Chinese Government and the Government of North Korea signed an Agreement on Mutual Supply of Critical Materials 1971-1976. Under the terms of this agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to provide the North Korean Government with 500,000 tons of crude oil per year.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Chinese Government donates 500,000 tons of crude oil in 2016

# Description
In 2016, the Chinese Government donated approximately 500,000 tons of crude oil to the North Korean Government. 500,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 3,665,000 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($158,657,850), AidData has taken the average price ($43.29) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) crude oil in 2016 and multiplied it by 3,665,000 barrels of oil. This crude oil donation project was supported via recurring grants from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) between 2000 and 2017.  Since 1991, China has been North Korea's largest crude oil provider, making up 80% of its supply. Crude oil is provided to North Korea through a pipeline (known as the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline or Friendship Oil Pipeline) from the Daqing Oil Field, 800 kilometers north of the China-North Korea border. The pipeline, which was completed in December 1975, runs for more than 30 km from storage facilities in the Chinese border city of Dandong to an oil depot in Sinuiju in North Korea. It supplies approximately 520,000 tons (3.64 million barrels) of heavy crude oil each year, according to its operator, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC). Once across the border, the crude oil is processed at North Korea's sole working refinery, the Ponghwa Chemical Factory, a facility built with Chinese assistance during the 1970s. The refinery turns the oil into refined products for North Korea's government, military, transport, agricultural and fishing sectors.
justification: Project involves donation of crude oil, which is a fossil fuel, and is part of ongoing oil supply infrastructure
evidence: 500,000 tons of crude oil donation, Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline infrastructure, supply to North Korea's refinery

title: China sent agricultural experts to hold an agricultural technology training course in North Korea in 2016
description: At the invitation of the Korean Federation of Science and Technology, a group of 6 agricultural production technology experts from Shandong Province, China visited the DPRK from August 19 to 25 and held special training courses on freshwater aquaculture and greenhouse vegetable cultivation technology.   The training class was held in the Grand People's Study House in Pyongyang. Scientific researchers and technicians from the North Korean National Science and Technology Commission, the National Academy of Sciences, the Academy of Agricultural Sciences, the Pyongyang Institute of Vegetable Science, and Kim Il-sung University participated in the training.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
China sent agricultural experts to hold an agricultural technology training course in North Korea in 2016

# Description
At the invitation of the Korean Federation of Science and Technology, a group of 6 agricultural production technology experts from Shandong Province, China visited the DPRK from August 19 to 25 and held special training courses on freshwater aquaculture and greenhouse vegetable cultivation technology.   The training class was held in the Grand People's Study House in Pyongyang. Scientific researchers and technicians from the North Korean National Science and Technology Commission, the National Academy of Sciences, the Academy of Agricultural Sciences, the Pyongyang Institute of Vegetable Science, and Kim Il-sung University participated in the training.
justification: Project focuses on knowledge transfer and agricultural training without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Agricultural technology training course, knowledge transfer in freshwater aquaculture and greenhouse vegetable cultivation

title: Chinese Government provides $200,000 cash grant to DRC’s Ministry of Public Health to support yellow fever vaccination efforts (Linked to Project ID#58863)
description: On August 10, 2016, China delivered a $200,000 check to the Congolese Ministry of Public Health for Yellow Fever vaccinations. The vaccination project was set to begin on August 17th, 2016. This project is completed.
staff_comments: A donation of medical equipment was made at the same time as this project, which is recorded in project #58863, but they appear to be two distinct donations.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government provides $200,000 cash grant to DRC’s Ministry of Public Health to support yellow fever vaccination efforts (Linked to Project ID#58863)

# Description
On August 10, 2016, China delivered a $200,000 check to the Congolese Ministry of Public Health for Yellow Fever vaccinations. The vaccination project was set to begin on August 17th, 2016. This project is completed.
justification: Project is a healthcare initiative focused on disease prevention with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Cash grant for yellow fever vaccination efforts, healthcare sector project

title: Chinese Government provides $1,552,842 grant for the 10th Phase of People's Palace Technical Cooperation Project (Linked to projects #31415, #58848, #58849, and #58850)
description: On January 1, 2016, the Chinese Government committed a $1,552,842.31 grant for the 10th Phase of People's Palace Technical Cooperation Project. The purpose of this project was to maintain and repair the People's Palace in Democratic Republic of Congo. According to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), no disbursements were made in support of this project. However, according to the 2019 MOFCOM Investment Guide, the 11th Phase of People's Palace Technical Cooperation Project is already underway.  The People's Palace Technical Cooperation Project has been undertaken in multiple phases:  6th phase (recorded in project #31415) 7th phase (recorded in #58848) 8th phase (recorded in #58849) 9th phase (recorded in #58850).  The French project title is 10ème Mission technique chinoise chargée de la maintenance du Palais du Peuple.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides $1,552,842 grant for the 10th Phase of People's Palace Technical Cooperation Project (Linked to projects #31415, #58848, #58849, and #58850)

# Description
On January 1, 2016, the Chinese Government committed a $1,552,842.31 grant for the 10th Phase of People's Palace Technical Cooperation Project. The purpose of this project was to maintain and repair the People's Palace in Democratic Republic of Congo. According to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), no disbursements were made in support of this project. However, according to the 2019 MOFCOM Investment Guide, the 11th Phase of People's Palace Technical Cooperation Project is already underway.  The People's Palace Technical Cooperation Project has been undertaken in multiple phases:  6th phase (recorded in project #31415) 7th phase (recorded in #58848) 8th phase (recorded in #58849) 9th phase (recorded in #58850).  The French project title is 10ème Mission technique chinoise chargée de la maintenance du Palais du Peuple.
justification: Project focuses on maintenance and repair of a cultural/social infrastructure facility with no direct energy or environmental implications
evidence: Maintenance and repair of People's Palace, social infrastructure focus, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Government donates medical equipment (Linked to Project ID #52164 and #58959)
description: On August 10, 2016, the Chinese government donated medical equipment to the Democratic Republic of Congo. The handover ceremony of the donation was held at the Sino-Congolese Friendship Hospital in Kinshasa, and was attended by Ambassador Wang Tongqing and Congolese Minister of Health Kabange Numbi. Project #58959, a 2015 grant for the provision of medical equipment, likely captures the transaction value of the medical equipment donated in this project. This project is completed.
staff_comments: A $200,000 donation of yellow fever vaccines was made at the same time as this project, which is recorded in project #52164, but they appear to be two distinct donations.
